metadata.bijbeltekst: Malachi 3:18–4:1; Luke 3:7; Matthew 3:12; Isaiah 2:4; Romans 3:22–23; John 5:24

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in a world of cosmic conflict and human self-righteousness to disarm the rebel and judge the 'old Adam' in Christ, thereby moving the hearer from death to life.

tekstueel_bewijs: God is on the move to disarm us all
He, the Son of God in person, became the Judge judged in our place
He gave himself to release us into life
release us into life and righteousness

zender.identificatie: The Triune God (Source of Justice and Mercy)
tekstueel_bewijs: God as the great arbiter of all things who brings justice
judgment to begin with the household of God

helper.identificatie: The Sacrifice of Christ / The Word
tekstueel_bewijs: fully absorbed into the crucified body of our Lord Jesus Christ
helper.rol_van_geest: Unclear (Spirit is implicit in the 'remaking' process)

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, Satan, and the 'Old Adam' (Self-Righteousness)
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just bad behavior but a 'rebel' nature and a cosmic 'onslaught' that requires a divine subject to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the disarmed Christian in a post-9/11 world.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Christian/The Church
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Humility, Human Rights, and Fighting Evil (not people)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ethical mandate to 'not lose its soul' is presented as a consequence of understanding one's own status as a 'judged' sinner under grace.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God is on the move to disarm us all.
He gave himself to release us.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We deal with insecurity by dividing up the world.
We always place ourselves on the side of the good guys.
We must be disarmed by God.

voorbeelden: America must not lose its soul.
a rebel who must lay down his arms.
we want to help out the economy.
we want to be able to define who the wicked are.
none of us knows what sorts of inner pressures another person is under.
he gave himself to release us into life.
He is remaking us into his image.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes the inability of the human subject (the rebel) to self-correct, focusing on God's 'Pouvoir' (Power) to disarm and remake the subject.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Starts at ~S2 (Panic/Anxiety), moves to S2 (Judgment/Malachi), exposes ~S1 (Self-righteousness of Falwell/Bin Laden), and resolves in S1 (Grace) via the 'Judge judged' (S2 absorbed).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by Christ taking S2 (Judgment) upon himself, allowing the Receiver to move from ~S2 to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. Judgment is not bypassed but 'fully absorbed' into Christ.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It systematically deconstructs human agency (the 'good guy' narrative) and replaces it with God's agency in Christ.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Now it is the firemen who are the heroes.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He, the Son of God in person, became the Judge judged in our place.
onslaught of Satan... slaves to sin and death.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Firefighters and Flight 93 passengers are used as 'reflectors' of Christ's sacrifice, but the sermon explicitly warns against 'idolizing' them, noting they are also sinners.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: John the Baptist (as a herald, not a model)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: Their sacrifice is a faint echo of the only true Subject's sacrifice.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and humility; the burden of being the 'hero' or 'judge' is removed.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the 'war zone' of 9/11 to the 'war zone' of the soul is seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between the need to 'stop' Bin Laden and the refusal to 'hate' him.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: became the Judge judged in our place.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is a 'rebellion' and 'dark formations' that inhabit even the 'household of God'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of the primary narrative program, using the 9/11 context not as a moralistic springboard but as a diagnostic for human helplessness.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on Devoir in the middle section regarding national soul.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current trajectory where Pouvoir (God's power) enables the Devoir.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'must not lose its soul' is explicitly linked to the Spirit's work.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Excellent; the opponent is internal and cosmic.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The sermon already avoids the 'light opponent' of mere bad habits.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterclass in grace-oriented preaching that uses a national crisis to deepen rather than flatten the Gospel.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 9/11 pathos; Greimas reveals the underlying 'Subject-switch' from the American hero to the Crucified God.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would explain Malachi's context; Greimas shows how the sermon uses Malachi as an 'Opponent' to the hearer's self-righteousness.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas exposes that the 'firemen' are not the true Subjects of the sermon, but 'Helpers' that point to the ultimate Subject (Christ).

appendices.notities: The sermon follows Fleming Rutledge's own homiletical theory perfectly.
